text:
SPEAKER 1: The
question was, what

advice do you have for the
faculty member to improve?
And the answer was quit.

SPEAKER 2: Don't get me wrong,
Professor Mayo is great.

But sometimes when he talks
about emotional things

or sensitive topics,
he has a flat line.
He shows no emotion.
Where's the emotion?
You want emotion?
This is emotion.

SPEAKER 3: Slightly clearer
speech would be helpful.

Sometimes I notice words
getting slurred or mixed up.

SPEAKER 4: Leah made things feel
real, and through direct back

and forth with students, forced
people to accept trade offs
and make hard choices.
My name is not Leah, actually.

Would have been more real if
you knew that my name was Laura.

SPEAKER 5: You need
to do a lot of prep

to really benefit
from each class.

When I don't do a great prep,
I tend to get nothing out
of the class.

I really don't know how
to rectify this situation.
Hm.
Let me think.
Maybe do a great prep.

SPEAKER 6: Please, Lord,
could Professor Berk

wear something other than
a suit with cufflinks?

SPEAKER 7: While I
appreciate the energy,

I think sometimes the
classroom feels cheesy

and the instructor's
charismatic reactions are
a little over the top.
She called me charismatic.

SPEAKER 8: Be more funny at
the beginning of the semester.

I guess that means I
was funny at the end?

SPEAKER 9: Professor
Snook, when I

was trying to decide whether
or not to take your course,

I asked your son, who's
also in my section,
if he was signing up for ALD.
His response?

Hell, I've been taking his
course for almost 30 years,
and look how screwed up I am.
Gee.
I love you, too, son.

SPEAKER 10: Though I
generally found the course

material interesting,
this was my least favorite
second-year class.
SPEAKER 11: She talks too fast.
Yeah, that's probably true.

But we have a lot of material
to cover, and only 80 minutes.

And so what are
my other options?

SPEAKER 12: Professor Berk
is too robotic and too
professional.

It is difficult for
me to open up to him.

SPEAKER 13: The most
effective aspect of the course

was the lady who
taught the class.
The lady?
Like Lady Leah?

SPEAKER 14:
Sometimes she told us

we had to figure out
things for ourselves.
Yeah.

SPEAKER 15: Your handwriting
looks like a serial killer's
letter to the police.

SPEAKER 16: Wang
sometimes gives off

an I don't really care vibe
when leading discussion.

I don't think this
is intentional.

You're right, I was
really going for the I
don't give a [BLEEP] vibe.

SPEAKER 17: The course has too
many readings by one author.
Is Michael Porter a god?
We sure treat him as one.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
